docs.lead_paragraph: CUBA, shaped like a scythe, lies in the Caribbean 90 miles off Florida. For centuries it has been a kind of fantasy island to the outside world. Columbus thought it was the prettiest place he had ever seen. Later adventurers went there for gold and found it: ''white gold,'' sugar. With African slaves to harvest the cane, they lived like grandees. By the 19th century and well into the 20th, the capital city, Havana, with its thick sea walls and rococo facades, was a cosmopolitan magnet for businessmen, artists and tourists alike. Its casinos were lavish; its night life was tireless. It was where you went to be extravagant, liberated and bad. Even the moralizing political liberation of the 1950's and 60's had its glamour. The revolutionary troops, with their scruffy-chic beards and berets, were popular international heroes for a time. And they were led by two genuine superstars: the baby-faced Fidel Castro and the Byronic Che Guevara. When their pictures appeared in the news, readers alternately flinched and swooned. With global capitalism triumphant, yet another fantasy is on the horizon: the revival of the island as the vacation spot it once was, a semitropical dream come true.

headline.main: Stylists Of the Epic And the Surreal

docs.abstract: Holland Cotter reviews photographs of Cuba in its revolutionary and post-revolutionary phases, at Grey Art Gallery and Cuban Art Space; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Planned Parenthood of South Carolina has filed suit against the issuance of state license plates that read ''Choose Life.'' Proceeds from the sale of the optional plates, which cost $70 every two years, are intended to help finance crisis pregnancy centers that do not provide or promote abortions. Planned Parenthood, which does provide abortions, argued that the law authorizing the plates violates constitutional guarantees of free speech and equal protection. Kevin Sack (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Abortion Fight

docs.lead_paragraph: ''For every life saved by vaccination or food relief, one is lost to starvation or war,'' writes Barbara Kingsolver in ''The Poisonwood Bible,'' her wonderful epic novel of Congo 40 years ago. ''Poor Africa. No other continent has endured such an unspeakably bizarre combination of foreign thievery and foreign good will.'' Governments have come and gone since then, but the bizarre and the unspeakable remain a constant. In a five-part ''Nightline'' series called ''Heart of Darkness,'' beginning on ABC at 11:35 tomorrow night, Ted Koppel delivers harrowing reporting on Congo today. His purpose is to unravel the causes of fighting, famine and disease that have killed 2.5 million Congolese in the last three years. The consequences were spread before the ''Nightline'' cameras in a banquet of despair. The program will resume on Tuesday for four nights.

headline.main: Telling the Story Of Congo's War, Amid the Chaos

docs.abstract: Julie Salamon's Critic's Notebook column appraises Heart of Darkness, five-part documentary on ABC's Nightline about Congo's civil war (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: KIM PALMER is a romantic who says she can write a letter that will make any person fall in love with any other. Her own love life, however, has been quiet since her husband died of AIDS a decade ago. They had met in school, married and had two sons. She is H.I.V. positive and has been alone since. ''I miss him,'' Mrs. Palmer, 44, said, ''but I am finally ready for another relationship. And at my age, sex has nothing to do with it. I just want to go to the movies, to hold hands, to have a companion.'' She paused, then shook her head. ''I just feel funny, because I've forgotten how to do it all.''
docs.abstract: Article on Camp Viva, weeklong summer camp in Pawling, NY, for economically disadvantaged people from Westchester County with HIV/AIDS and their families; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The District of Columbia Fire Department has begun an internal investigation into whether agency officials influenced some employees to have abortions. The agency said today that it was investigating accusations that a cadet orientation earlier this year left new emergency medical technicians with the impression that if they became pregnant during a one-year probationary period, they would lose their jobs. Acting out of such fear, three women from a class of 10 to 15 new cadets claimed they had abortions, union officials said.

headline.main: Officials Look Into Whether Cadets Were Influenced on Abortion

docs.abstract: Washington, DC, Fire Department says it probes whether new emergency medical technicians were influenced to have abortions because they were given impression they would lose jobs if they were pregnant during one-year probationary period; three female cadets claim they had abortions out of fear of losing jobs; veteran firefighters reportedly have come forward with similar charges (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco signed legislation today requiring insurance companies that offer pregnancy-related benefits to also provide coverage for a wide range of infertility treatments. The legislation, which has been criticized by insurance companies, makes New Jersey the 15th state to enact legislation regarding infertility therapy. The scope of the laws varies widely from state to state, but advocacy groups called the New Jersey law a reasonable compromise that includes provisions for costly treatments like in vitro fertilization, but that also limits when such methods can be used.

headline.main: Insurers Offering Pregnancy Benefits Now Must Cover Fertility
